description.value:
Ogrémoch makes two slam attacks.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Melee Weapon Attack: +14 to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 4d10 + @mod type=bludgeoning average=true]] damage.

The [[lookup @name]] attacks with its [[lookup @item.name]].

Ranged Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, range 500 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 7d10 + @mod + 8 type=bludgeoning average=true]] damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save str 23 format=long]] or be knocked &Reference[prone]{prone}.

The [[lookup @name]] attacks with its [[lookup @item.name]].

Ogrémoch summons up to three earth elemental;earth elementals and loses 30 hit points for each &Reference[elemental]{elemental} he summons. Summoned elementals have maximum hit points, appear within 100 feet of Ogrémoch, and disappear if Ogrémoch is reduced to 0 hit points.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Lair Actions

Ogrémoch can assert his dominion over the rock and stone around him to take lair actions on the &Reference[elemental]{Elemental} Plane of Earth, or in any &Reference[elemental]{elemental} earth node (including the Black Geode, described in chapter 5). On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Ogrémoch uses his lair action to cause one of the following effects:

  • A 10-foot-radius area of rocky or earthy ground within 60 feet of Ogrémoch turns to sticky mud. Any creature on the ground in the area must succeed on a [[/save dex 15 format=long]] or sink 5 feet into the mud and be &Reference[restrained]{restrained}. A creature can take an action to make a DC 15 &Reference[str]{Strength} check, ending the effect on itself or another creature within its reach on a success.
  • Crystalline spikes grow from the ground in a 20-foot-radius area within 60 feet of Ogrémoch. The area becomes difficult terrain. A creature that moves through the affected area takes 1d[[/damage 8 piercing average=false]] damage for every 5 feet it moves there. Creatures that are knocked &Reference[prone]{prone} in the area also take this damage.
  • A violent tremor shakes the lair in a 120-foot-radius around Ogrémoch. Each creature other than Ogrémoch on the ground in the area must succeed on a DC 15 &Reference[str]{Strength} or &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throw (target’s choice) or be knocked &Reference[prone]{prone}.
The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Regional Effects

The region containing an &Reference[elemental]{elemental} node in which Ogrémoch is present is seriously affected, becoming geologically unstable. This creates the following effects:

  • Earth tremors strike the region within 10 miles of Ogrémoch’s location every 2d12 hours, each lasting 1d10 rounds. At first, damage is minor — broken windows, cracked plaster, items toppled off shelves. The longer Ogrémoch remains, the stronger the tremors become. After 5 days, the tremors are strong enough to destroy flimsy structures. After 10 days, they are strong enough to destroy ordinary wooden buildings. After 20 days, they can seriously damage or destroy reinforced or fortified structures.
  • Magnetic disturbances within 10 miles of Ogrémoch prevent compasses from functioning there.
  • Hidden sinkholes and fissures form within 1 mile of Ogrémoch’s location. A hidden sinkhole can be spotted from a safe distance by any creature with a passive &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} (&Reference[prc]{Perception}) score of 15 or higher or spotted with a successful DC 15 &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} (&Reference[sur]{Survival}) check. Otherwise, the first creature to step on the thin crust covering the sinkhole must succeed on a [[/save dex 15 format=long]] or fall 1d6 × 10 feet into the sinkhole or fissure.
  • Natural caves and tunnels within 1 mile of Ogrémoch’s lair form intermittent portals to the &Reference[elemental]{Elemental} Plane of Earth, allowing &Reference[elemental]{elemental} creatures into the mortal world to dwell near those points.

If Ogrémoch is destroyed or banished back to his home plane, the regional effects fade over the next 1d10 days.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Ogrémoch’s Lair


Ogrémoch is normally found in the depths of &Reference[elemental]{elemental} earth, choosing caverns with black crystals and jagged rock spikes to serve as his throne room. He can enter the &Reference[material]{Material} Plane through large and well-established nodes of &Reference[elemental]{elemental} earth, with a little help from the proper rituals. Within such a node, Ogrémoch wields great power.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Ogrémoch can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Ogrémoch regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

Illuminating Crystals. Ogrémoch’s crystalline protrusions flare. Each creature within 30 feet of Ogrémoch becomes outlined in orange light, shedding dim light in a 10-foot radius. Any attack roll against an affected creature has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature can’t benefit from being &Reference[invisible]{invisible}.

Stomp (Costs 2 Actions). Ogrémoch stomps the ground, creating an earth tremor that extends in a 30-foot radius. Other creatures standing on the ground in that radius must succeed on a [[/save dex 23 format=long]] or fall &Reference[prone]{prone}.

Create Gargoyle (Costs 3 Actions). Ogrémoch’s hit points are reduced by 50 as he breaks off a chunk of his body and places it on the ground in an unoccupied space within 15 feet of him. The chunk of rock instantly transforms into a gargoyle and acts on the same initiative count as Ogrémoch. Ogrémoch can’t use this action if he has 50 hit points or fewer. The gargoyle obeys Ogrémoch’s commands and fights until destroyed.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Ogrémoch’s crystalline protrusions flare. Each creature within 30 feet of Ogrémoch becomes outlined in orange light, shedding dim light in a 10-foot radius. Any attack roll against an affected creature has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature can’t benefit from being &Reference[invisible]{invisible}.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Ogrémoch stomps the ground, creating an earth tremor that extends in a 30-foot radius. Other creatures standing on the ground in that radius must succeed on a [[/save dex 23 format=long]] or fall &Reference[prone]{prone}.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]] and a save is required.

Ogrémoch’s hit points are reduced by 50 as he breaks off a chunk of his body and places it on the ground in an unoccupied space within 15 feet of him. The chunk of rock instantly transforms into a gargoyle and acts on the same initiative count as Ogrémoch. Ogrémoch can’t use this action if he has 50 hit points or fewer. The gargoyle obeys Ogrémoch’s commands and fights until destroyed.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Empowered Attacks. Ogrémoch’s slam attacks are treated as magical and adamantine for the purpose of bypassing resistance and immunity to nonmagical weapons.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Innate Spellcasting. Ogrémoch’s innate spellcasting ability is &Reference[cha]{Charisma} (spell save DC 20, +12 to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no &Reference[material]{material} components:

At will: meld into stone, move earth, wall of stone

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Legendary Resistance (3/Day). If Ogrémoch fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Magic Resistance. Ogrémoch has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Siege Monster. Ogrémoch deals double damage to objects and structures with his melee and ranged weapon attacks.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

You step into a stone object or surface large enough to fully contain your body, melding yourself and all the equipment you carry with the stone for the duration. Using your movement, you step into the stone at a point you can touch. Nothing of your presence remains visible or otherwise detectable by nonmagical senses.

While merged with the stone, you can't see what occurs outside it, and any &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} (&Reference[prc]{Perception}) checks you make to hear sounds outside it are made with disadvantage. You remain aware of the passage of time and can cast spells on yourself while merged in the stone. You can use your movement to leave the stone where you entered it, which ends the spell. You otherwise can't move.

Minor physical damage to the stone doesn't harm you, but its partial destruction or a change in its shape (to the extent that you no longer fit within it) expels you and deals 6d6 &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage to you. The stone's complete destruction (or &Reference[trs]{transmutation} into a different substance) expels you and deals 50 &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage to you. If expelled, you fall &Reference[prone]{prone} in an unoccupied space closest to where you first entered.

Choose an area of terrain no larger than 40 feet on a side within range. You can reshape dirt, sand, or clay in the area in any manner you choose for the duration. You can raise or lower the area’s elevation, create or fill in a trench, erect or flatten a wall, or form a pillar. The extent of any such changes can’t exceed half the area’s largest dimension. So, if you affect a 40-foot square, you can create a pillar up to 20 feet high, raise or lower the square’s elevation by up to 20 feet, dig a trench up to 20 feet deep, and so on. It takes 10 minutes for these changes to complete.

At the end of every 10 minutes you spend concentrating on the spell, you can choose a new area of terrain to affect.

Because the terrain’s transformation occurs slowly, creatures in the area can’t usually be trapped or injured by the ground’s movement.

This spell can’t manipulate natural stone or stone construction. Rocks and structures shift to accommodate the new terrain. If the way you shape the terrain would make a structure unstable, it might collapse.

Similarly, this spell doesn’t directly affect &Reference[plant]{plant} growth. The moved earth carries any plants along with it.

A nonmagical wall of solid stone springs into existence at a point you choose within range. The wall is 6 inches thick and is composed of ten 10-foot- by-10-foot panels. Each panel must be contiguous with at least one other panel. Alternatively, you can create 10-foot-by-20-foot panels that are only 3 inches thick.

If the wall cuts through a creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (your choice). If a creature would be surrounded on all sides by the wall (or the wall and another solid surface), that creature can make a &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throw. On a success, it can use its reaction to move up to its speed so that it is no longer enclosed by the wall.

The wall can have any shape you desire, though it can't occupy the same space as a creature or object. The wall doesn't need to be vertical or rest on any firm foundation. It must, however, merge with and be solidly supported by existing stone. Thus, you can use this spell to bridge a chasm or create a ramp.

If you create a span greater than 20 feet in length, you must halve the size of each panel to create supports. You can crudely shape the wall to create crenellations, battlements, and so on.

The wall is an object made of stone that can be damaged and thus breached. Each panel has AC 15 and 30 hit points per inch of thickness. Reducing a panel to 0 hit points destroys it and might cause connected panels to collapse at the GM's discretion.

If you maintain your &Reference[concentration]{concentration} on this spell for its whole duration, the wall becomes permanent and can't be dispelled. Otherwise, the wall disappears when the spell ends.
